Award.AbstractNarration:
Borehole temperatures provide a history of the surface temperature variability and are thus extremely useful for paleoclimate reconstructions. A database of borehole temperatures was produced by researchers at the University of Michigan and has been available for the research community for about 15 years. It is in need of updating and expanding, which is the principal aim of this project. The Principal Investigator of this project is one of the original authors of the database. The five goals of the project are: 1) to renovate and maintain the database with the latest online database technology; 2) to continue data acquisition for better geographical coverage; 3) to refine the climate reconstruction techniques to improve surface temperature reconstructions of the past several millennia or more; 4) to assess the uncertainties of the borehole reconstructions and how they compare to traditional proxy-based reconstructions; and 5) to compare the borehole reconstructions with Climate Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) model simulations to evaluate the energy fluxes across the ground surface and the change in heat content of the near surface solid earth since the last glacial maximum.

The broader impacts include some undergraduate student training and mentoring, but principally the development of an accessible database of borehole temperatures in collaboration with the National Climate Data Center, Paleoclimatology Branch.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global climate change is a major scientific and socioeconomic challenge of our age. To be able to predict the future climate, we need to learn from the past, including paleoclimate histories and the energy exchanges among Earth system components over the course of climate change. The major goal of this P2C2 project “Geothermal Research into Paleoclimate” is to further advance the on-going geothermal research into paleoclimate change to provide surface temperature history reconstructions and to gain a better understanding of the climate effects under the ground.

It has been widely recognized among the scientific community that underground temperature comprises an independent archive of information on climate change which is complementary to the meteorological and other climate proxy records. However, due to various perturbations, borehole temperature profiles qualified for a climate history reconstruction are precious. After parsing through several national data archives and field campaigns, our data acquisition effort added 60 new members to the Global Database of Borehole Temperatures for Climate Reconstruction, which currently embraces 1012 borehole sites. The updated database is accessible at the University of Michigan http://www.earth.lsa.umich.edu/climate/ and at the NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information (formerly National Climate Data Center) at https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/data-access/paleoclimatology-data/datasets/borehole. The aggregated global climate reconstruction shows a progressively accelerated warming over the past five centuries with an accumulated warming of about 1 K.

The warming on the ground surface has impacts on the temperature distribution beneath the ground surface. It imposes transient perturbation to the thermal regime of the uppermost layer of lithosphere and, hence, exerts impact on the energy flux across the ground surface. In this regard, continental lithosphere is an important regulator of the energy budget of global climate system. Great efforts have been devoted to detect and attribute the heat content changes of global oceans and atmosphere. Less well understood is the extent of subsurface warming of the global lands. We examined the annual heat content change of the continental landmasses over the period from 1850 to 2015 based on meteorological records and extended the analysis to Year 2100 under three climate scenarios. Our study shows that the global landmasses have absorbed 19 ZJ (1021 Joules) of thermal energy, more than twice as much thermal energy as the entire atmosphere since the beginning of the 20th century global climate warming. If the observed global warming trend over the past 25 years (1991-2015) is to continue at 2.89K/100a, an additional 51 ZJ of heat will be trapped underground by the end of the 21st century. Even if the global surface temperature is to stabilize at the current state throughout the rest of the 21st century, the continental landmasses will continue to acquire over 15 ZJ extra energy from the atmosphere. An overall 0.72 K cooling at the global ground surface between now and 2100 is required to avoid further heating of the continents.

From the perspective of the Earth’s climate change since the Last Glaciation Maximum (LGM), although the pace of climate change over the past one and a half centuries is anomaly high, the magnitude is not. The LGM refers to the last time when the Earth was most extensively covered by ice sheets about 22,000 years ago. Over a deglaciation period of several thousand years after the LGM, the Earth warmed by 4-8 K to a climate state comparable to the present. To investigate the landmass thermal response to the last deglaciation, we compiled a database of 88 high resolution paleoclimate reconstructions over the period 22-6 kybp (thousand years before present) available at the NOAA Paleoclimatology Program. Each reconstruction is normalized with respect to its maximum-minimum range. The normalized time series are integrated into three synthesized global representations of magnitudes of 4K, 6K, and 8K, respectively. We estimate that over the deglaciation period, the continental landmass absorbed 0.95-1.52 YJ (1024 Joules) of thermal energy.

The climate change originated downward heat flux would affect the flow of heat from the interior of the Earth, termed as terrestrial heat flow, or heat flow in short. Heat flow near the surface consists of a crustal component and a mantle component. The crustal heat flow component is mainly due to the decays of radioactive elements of uranium, thorium, and potassium. Therefore, heat flow is anticipated to monotonically decrease with increasing depth. However, such an anticipated monotonic relationship is reflected neither in the global heat flow database, nor in the measurements made in several deep boreholes around the world. Among many factors that may affect the variation of heat flow with depth, it is widely recognized that long term climate change must play an important role. Our analysis shows that if left uncorrected, continental heat flow might be underestimated by up to 30% due to Holocene climate change.
